headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALSON, ELIZABETH "LIBBY" LEE

docs.snippet: ALSON--Elizabeth "Libby" Lee, 80, died on August 28, 2014. Born in Bronxville, she attended Horace Greeley and Radcliffe, worked for McCall's and Knopf, assisted director Joseph Mankiewicz, and curated at Caramoor museum. Libby loved the arts, tra...
docs.lead_paragraph: ALSON--Elizabeth "Libby" Lee, 80, died on August 28, 2014. Born in Bronxville, she attended Horace Greeley and Radcliffe, worked for McCall's and Knopf, assisted director Joseph Mankiewicz, and curated at Caramoor museum. Libby loved the arts, travel, nature, animals, and people. She will be greatly missed by her husband Larry, daughter Kate, stepson Peter, son-in-law Jason, daughter-in-law Alice, sister Helen, stepsister Mary, sister-in-law Elaine, her grandchildren Eliot and Eden, and a legion of family and friends. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to: Pets Alive: petsalivewest.org A memorial will be held at Croton Point Park.

headline.print_headline: Factory Activity in Europe, Asia Cools; Demand Lull a Concern
headline.main: Factory Activity in Europe, Asia Cools; Demand Lull a Concern

docs.snippet: Factory activity in Europe and Asia cooled in August after a strong July, as new orders dwindled in the face of escalating tensions in Ukraine and a patchy recovery in China, purchasing managers indexes showed....
docs.lead_paragraph: Factory activity in Europe and Asia cooled in August after a strong July, as new orders dwindled in the face of escalating tensions in Ukraine and a patchy recovery in China, purchasing managers indexes showed.

headline.name: Israeli Couscous, Eggplant and Tomato Gratin
headline.main: Couscous Salads, Big Bowls and Casseroles

docs.snippet: This is an eggplant Parmesan of sorts on top of a bed of Israeli couscous. If you’ve made fresh tomato sauce over the summer or you’re still getting wonderful tomatoes at the farmers’ market, use fresh tomato sauce; otherwise, use canned tom...

multimedia.credit: Andrew Scrivani for The New York Times
Andrew Scrivani for The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: This is an eggplant Parmesan of sorts on top of a bed of Israeli couscous. If you’ve made fresh tomato sauce over the summer or you’re still getting wonderful tomatoes at the farmers’ market, use fresh tomato sauce; otherwise, use canned tomatoes for your marinara sauce. You can substitute cooked grains for the Israeli couscous; if you don’t tolerate gluten, try the recipe using cooked brown rice instead. I like to use Japanese or baby Italian eggplants for this.

headline.print_headline: Fast-Food Workers to Launch Intensified Protests Across U.S.
headline.main: Fast-Food Workers to Launch Intensified Protests Across U.S.
